questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with an acute stroke. On examination he has mild right arm and face weakness. He has spontaneous speech with occasional paraphasic errors. He can understand and follow commands. Repetition is severely impaired. Which of the following best explains his speech pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Conduction aphasia

In the given case, the patient has Right Facio-brachial paralysis indicating lesion in the left hemisphere (Dominant/Categorical hemisphere) of the brain which houses speech areas.

In the given case, comprehension & fluency is intact but repetition is severely impaired indicating damage to the Arcuate Fasciculus which connects the Wernicke’s to the Broca’s area

questions.text: During a neurological examination, you ask a patient to stand with both hands fully extended and parallel to the ground with eyes closed for 10 seconds. What is the name of the test ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Pronator drift
It is a sign of distal muscle weakness due to corticospinal injury, hence used as a sensitive sign of stroke in the ER.

questions.text: 24yrs, Primi-gravida presents to the casualty with generalised tonic-clonic convulsions. She is 28weeks pregnant. She was found to have elevated BP 160/100mm of Hg. Fundus examination revealed Papilledema. Neurological examination revealed Right sided hemiparesis. MRI was performed. What is best management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Start Anti-coagulation.
Patient is suffering from Dural Venous sinus thrombosis as revealed on MR Venography.
The treatment of choice is Anticoagulation

questions.text: A 63-year-old female presented to the emergency room with an acute aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and underwent a clipping procedure on admission. She has since been recovering in the intensive care unit. On the tenth postoperative day, she was noted to have slurred speech, worsening right facial droop, and right arm weakness. She was more difficult to rouse. NCCT and four-vessel angiogram are shown shows ischemia in MCA territory. Which of the following is the best treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Intra-arterial calcium channel blockers.
SAH is due to blood in the CSF. Even after treatment of the cause e.g. aneurysm as in the given case by clipping, delayed complication can occur. The neurodeficit in SAH is due to VASOSPASM & is best treated by CCB -Nimodipine

choices.text: Maybe Spontaneous in Elderly and alcoholics
Source of bleeding is Bridging veins
Prognosis with early surgery is excellent

questions.text: Following statements about Subdural hematoma are true Except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Collection is between Dura and Arachnoid matter.
•	Elderly & Alcoholics can develop Spontaneous hematoma
•	Source is tearing in the bridging veins
•	35-40% may have Lucid interval
•	Despite Surgical decompression, prognosis is poor due to underlying brain injury

questions.text: A 14yrs boy was brought to Neurology clinic with myoclonic jerks. The boy who had received good grades in Primary school, had difficulty in even passing his 7th standard examination. The parents were stressed with his worsening grades. A recent visit to an ophthalmologist had detected defect in visual acuity. He had no siblings and his vaccination was complete. EEG was performed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
SSPE also known as Dawson’s encephalitis. EEG shows Rademaker’s complex.

SSPE is a chronic disease due to measles infection. Majority patients are below 15 years of age.  Most common presenting symptom are scholastic backwardness (52.5%) followed by myoclonic seizures (23.5%). Few patients may have cortical blindness, macular degeneration, decreased visual acuity, and optic atrophy. Electroencephalographic (EEG) shows long interval periodic complexes which are diagnostic of the disease. Only 60% patients give a history of measles infection during childhood. Vaccination is not fool proof against development of SSPE

questions.text: You have just admitted a young man with past h/o seizure disorder who has just witnessed to have a focal seizure. His family’s description is s/o focal seizure involving left half of body. No h/o LOC. He was brought 2 hrs. After symptom onset, currently he is awake, conscious & oriented but power in left UL is 0/5 with rest of neuronal examination WNL.NCCT(Brain) done is WNL. Best course of action at this time is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Reassess in few hours
In the given case patient is suffering with post ictal paralysis following focal seizure -TODD’S PARALYSIS. Todd’s paralysis can be partial or complete. It can persist for 30 minutes to 36 hours, with an average of 15 hours, at which point it resolves completely. It can affect speech and vision too on rare occasions. It is self-recoverable so reassessment is the best action.
Differentiation from Stroke is important as the management is completely different. In this case, the distribution of the weakness and the Normal NCCT excludes stroke

choices.text: Immediately taper valproate and start lamotrigine
Continue valproate with monitoring of drug level

questions.text:
A 29-year old, 4-month pregnant primigravida has a h/o juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. She has been regularly taking sodium valproate and now seeking an opinion for her antiepileptic regimen.
What would you suggest her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Continue Valproate with monitoring of drug levels

Epilepsy in Pregnancy is an important topic. There is an equal amount of Epilepsy which worsen or improve during pregnancy and hence standard treatment guidelines are laid down as follows.

1. In pregnancy, attempt for Monotherapy, whenever possible

2. Drug level monitoring can help maintain therapeutic levels with lowest doses

3. Do not change the AED on which the mother is controlled.

4. All AED’s are Category C drugs

5. Universal Folic acid supplementation to prevent neural tube defects

questions.text:
Following statements about Drug-Resistant Epilepsy (DRE) are true

Uncontrolled disease inspite of 2 or more trials with appropriate anti-epileptic drugs

2. Patients with DRE are prone to sudden unexpected death in Epilepsy (SUDEP)

3. Evaluation to assess if patient is a candidate for Brain surgery is not indicated

4. Disconnective brain surgery which prevents spread of seizure is most common surgical procedure in Epilepsy patients

5. Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy responds best to surgery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
1,2,5 are true statements

DRE is defined as uncontrolled disease inspite of 2 or more trials with appropriate anti-epileptic drugs in well tolerated doses. Other than the risk of fall and injury, the patients with DRE are prone to sudden unexpected death in Epilepsy (SUDEP). Evaluation to assess if patient is a candidate for Brain surgery is indicated as the chance of control by medical therapy alone is <4%. Non-pharmacological measures also aid the treatment. Resective surgery in which epileptogenic focus is identified and resected is the commonly done procedure in Epilepsy patients. Most common is Partial Temporal lobectomy in Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy in which anteromedial part is resected.

choices.text: Steroids should not be used as patient is diabetic

questions.text: A 78-year-old diabetic presents with signs & symptoms of meningitis. CSF examination shows following picture 100% neutrophils, glucose 10mg/dl and protein 78 mg/dl. Empirical therapy should include which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
For treatment Of PYOGENIC MENINGITIS Steroid is given prior to antibiotics.

Considering history of Diabetes, Fungal meningitis is a potential diagnosis necessitating Amphotericin B infusion. However, in fungal meningitis, the CSF glucose must be normal/mildly low. Pleocytic lymphocytosis is expected with an elevated protein levels in the CSF.

The CSF glucose is 2/3rd the plasma glucose concentration (60% of plasma).  In the given case, the CSF glucose is 10mg/dl (As per Harrison, CSF glucose < 60mg/dl is virtually diagnostic of pyogenic meningitis) The elevated neutrophils count along with elevated protein also favour pyogenic meningitis. The treatment is Dexamethasone prior to empirical antibiotics.
The empirical antibiotic preferred is 3rd generation cephalosporin in all cases of pyogenic meningitis. In elderly, IV Ampicillin is added to cover Listeria infection

choices.text: Lancosamide with biopsy of the lesion.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has recently moved from Delhi. He suffers a focal seizure followed by secondary generalization. He denies symptoms of active infection and has not suffered any recent trauma. His neurological examination has returned to normal in the emergency room. A magnetic resonance image (MRI) of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Levotiracetam with Albendazole

A ring enhancing with significant perilesional edema in a patient with seizure & no other foci of infection is suggestive of Neurocysticercosis (NCC). Treatment includes AED with albendazole

choices.text: Patient commonly presents with visual & speech disturbance.
It is most commonly seen in immunocompromised host.
Brain biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis
It follows an indolent course and patient usually dies within 6 months

questions.text: All of the following statements about PMLE are true except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
It follows an indolent course and patient usually dies within 6 months.

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PMLE) is an AIDS defining complex and commonly occurs in immune-compromised hosts. It is due to JC virus which is usually a commensal in the brain. Majority present with diplopia and speech disturbance. Demonstration of JC virus in the CSF with typical MRI finding are used for diagnosis. However, brain biopsy is the gold standard. The prognosis was grave in pre-HAART era. However, after introduction of HAART, there is only 10-30% mortality in the first 6 months

questions.text: Headache is among the most common condition seeking medical attention. Following features suggest a serious underlying disorder EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Onset before 55 years is usually Benign. Ref: Harrison 20th edition,

Headache Symptoms That Suggest a Serious Underlying Disorder (TABLE 13-2) : Pg 86.

  1. Sudden-onset headache
  2. First severe headache
  3. “Worst” headache ever
  4. Vomiting that precedes headache
  5. Subacute worsening over days or weeks
  6. Pain induced by bending, lifting, cough
  7. Pain that disturbs sleep or presents immediately upon awakening
  8. Known systemic illness
  9. Onset after age 55
  10. Fever or unexplained systemic signs
  11. Abnormal neurologic examination
  12. Pain associated with local tenderness, e.g., region of temporal artery

choices.text: Migraine attacks interfering with daily routine inspite of acute treatment
Migraine attacks are refractory to acute treatment resulting in overuse

questions.text: Migraine Prophylaxis is indicated in following patients EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Attacks >=3 /month

2019 – Migraine management guidelines update: Consider preventive treatment for migraine patients in the following situations:

  • Migraine attacks are frequent (≥4 migraine headache days per month) and/or the attacks interfere with patients' daily routines even with acute treatment
  • There is contradiction to, failure, or overuse of acute treatments
  • Acute treatments lead to adverse events
  • Oral treatments should be offered for migraine prevention. These include antiepileptic drugs, beta-blockers, and frovatriptan.
  • Do not prescribe valproate sodium and topiramate to women who are not using birth control and who may become pregnant.
  • Start oral treatments at a low dose and titrate slowly.

Give oral treatments for at least 8 weeks to optimize therapeutic response

choices.text: It is a Calcitonin-gene-related peptide receptor antagonist (CGRP)
It is approved for Migraine management
It is effective in management of acute attack of Migraine

questions.text: Following statements about Erenumab are true EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Erenumab is approved for chronic prophylaxis of Migraine only

choices.text: Average age of onset is 65 years
Number of neurofibrillary tangles is associated with the severity of dementia
Retrograde amnesia can occur early and precedes anterograde amnesia

questions.text: All of the following are true about Alzheimer’s disease except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Retrograde amnesia can occur early and precedes anterograde amnesia


Alzheimer’s disease is a neuro-degenerative disorder characterised by Neuro-fibrillary tangles (NFT-also called tau/tangles) and Senile plaques disproportionate to age. The number of NFT correlates with severity of the disease.  
The average age of onset is 65 years and is estimated to the third most common cause of death in the US, behind heart disease and cancer.  It is the most common cause of dementia among older adults. The damage begins in the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex causing anterograde amnesia before causing generalised atrophy of the brain responsible for retrograde amnesia

choices.text: Associated with involvement of Frontal and Parietal lobe dominantly
Associated with Capgras syndrome in majority cases during early stages
Neuroimaging shows Effacement of Sulci & gyri along with dilated ventricles
Apo E2 is the Protective Allele

questions.text: True Statement about Alzheimer’s disease is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Apo E2 is less common but protective allele in Alzheimer’s disease.
Alzheimer’s is a neuro-degenerative disorder affecting elderly males. It is associated with generalised atrophy of the brain predominantly affecting temporal and parietal lobes. MRI shows ex-cavuo dilatation of the ventricles with prominence of sulci and gyri. Apo E1 is commonly associated and increase risk of inheritance. ApoE2 is protective

questions.text: A 60-year-old alcoholic male presented with urinary incontinence and abnormal gait since 3 months. He also complains of loss of memory. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus 
NPH presents with a triad of ataxia, dementia with urinary incontinence. 
Onset occurs between 40-60 years with a male preponderance. 
MRI reveals Dilated ventricles with effacement of the sulci and gyri.
Treatment is VP shunt with Acetazolamide offering palliative relief

choices.text: Gradual onset with upper limb involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Conus medullaris syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Urinary retention with overflow incontinence. 

Conus medullaris syndrome usually follows trauma to lower back, hence onset is sudden.
The cord involvement corresponds to spinal segments S1-S5 and hence motor weakness affects lower limbs (Distal>Proximal). Considering that the spinal cord (UMN) is involved, there is hyperreflexia with exaggerated DTR (EXCEPT LOSS OF ANKLE JERK) . It is usually symmetrical considering the anatomy of the cord. Early Bladder involvement with urinary retention with overflow incontinence is typical of the disease

questions.text: A young man has suddenly developed paraplegia following a short febrile illness. Examination reveals lower motor neuron type paralysis with no sensory disturbances and no bladder and bowel involvement. The CSF examination in this case of likely to reveal
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Albumino-cytologic dissociation.
Paraparesis following febrile illness can be transverse myelitis vs Gullian Barre syndrome. 
In the given case, there is LMN type of paresis with no sensory involvement and normal bladder function favouring diagnosis of GBS. Hence, CSF finding of elevated protein with normal cell count i.e. albumin-cytological dissociation is characteristic

questions.text: A 9-yr-old girl has difficulty in combing hairs and climbing upstairs since 6 months. She has a maculopapular rash over metacarpophalangeal joints. What should be the next appropriate investigation to be done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Creatine kinase

Proximal myopathy with GOTTRONS RASH is suggestive of DERMATOMYOSITIS .CK is raised in it

questions.text: Which type of multiple sclerosis is depicted in the following image ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
SPMS

In the image, the initial episodes of MS show recovery. In later half, there is no recovery, hence SPMS.

questions.text: Match the following disease with their corresponding scoring/grading system:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

a-2, b-3, c-4, d-5

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition associated with the sign demonstrated in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

. Myotonia can be seen in the image. Myotonia means impaired relaxation of the muscle after activation. Myotonia syndromes can be due to channelopathies or myotonic dystrophy.

Myotonia due to channelopathies typically manifests in Adolescence & worsens with stress

Diagnosis is clinical. With Reassurance. Benign disease

Myotonic dystrophy is a long-term genetic disorder that affects muscle function. Symptoms include gradually worsening muscle loss and weakness. Muscles often contract and are unable to relax. Other symptoms may include cataracts, intellectual disability and heart conduction problems. In men, there may be early balding and an inability to have children

questions.text: Very slow, irregular, twisting movement, one movement perpetually blending with another is called
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Athetosis.

Involuntary movements indicate defect of Basal Ganglia Complex. The common ones are:

a. Athetosis is usually due to defect in the Putamen. It is slow sinuous writhing movement resembling a CRAWLING movement of distal upper limb where one movement blend with another.

b. Chorea usually indicates defect of Caudate Nucleus and described as Quasi-purposive (Semi-purposive) movements.

c. Hemiballismus indicates defect of Subthalamic Nucleus and is flinging, violent movement involving proximal joints and can lead to serious accidents/injury

choices.text: Only a is the true statement

questions.text:
Parkinson Plus syndromes are characterised by the following feature/s

a.Early onset of dementia

b. Late onset of Autonomic dysfunction

c. Excellent response to Syndopa therapy

d. Marked symmetry in early stages
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Both a & d

Following are features of Parkinson Plus syndromes different from PD

  • Poor response to Syndopa
  • Early onset of dementia/postural instability
  • Early onset psychosis with low dose Syndopa
  • Early ocular signs, pyramidal & autonomic symptoms
  • Marked symmetry in early stages
  • Truncal more than Appendicular symptoms

questions.text: 63yrs. Gentleman presented with history of recurrent falls. On examination, there was cog-wheel rigidity present. He has no family history of similar disease. He is non-alcoholic and denies any history of head trauma in the past. Inferior gaze is affected on evaluation. MRI was performed. The most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

D. PSP (Steele Richardson syndrome) is a Parkinson Plus syndrome. Patient has restriction of Inferior gaze which results in recurrent falls. MRI show Hummingbird sign

questions.text: Area marked as 3 is the area for auscultating which cardiac lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
HOCM is sub valvular obstruction and its murmur is heard at Erb’s (Neo-Aortic) area. AR due to aortic root dilatation is best heard at right parasternal area

questions.text: An 80 years old man with past history of AMI is found to have LBBB on ECG. He is asymptomatic; on cardiac auscultation the most likely finding is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Second heart sound (S2) is composed of aortic closure followed by pulmonic closure. Because inspiration increases blood return to the right side of heart, pulmonic closure is delayed which results in normal splitting of S2 during inspiration. Paradoxical or reverse splitting of S2 refers to narrowed splitting of S2 during inspiration as compared with expiration because pulmonic closure precedes aortic closure. It can occur in the following - LBBB, Aortic stenosis, HOCM, severe hypertension, and RV pacemaker

questions.text: On auscultation, a patient is found to have splitting of the second heart sound which increases during expiration. Which ONE of the following disorders does not cause this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Normally splitting of the second heart sound increases when the breath is held in inspiration, due to P2 delay. If the splitting of S2 decreases during inspiration & increases during expiration it means the patient has reverse splitting of the S2. The causes of reverse splitting are – LBBB, Aortic stenosis, HOCM, severe hypertension, and RV pacemaker

questions.text: Each of the following heart sounds occurs shortly after S2, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
MVP prolapse causes a late systolic murmur preceded by a click. It occurs before S2.

questions.text: A young basketball player with height 188 cm and arm span 197 cm has a diastolic murmur best heard in second right’ intercostals space. Likely cause of murmur is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Aortic root dilatation in Marfan’s syndrome leading to AR. (Arm span > 1.03*Height)
Other marfanoid features include high arched palate, arachnodactly, hyperlaxity

questions.text: MR can present with
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
All of the above
MR has many causes and the murmur can vary based on cause and its presentation.
In Acute MR  Early systolic murmur
In Chronic MR  Pan systolic murmur
In MR due to MVP  Late systolic murmur

questions.text: In this diagram consider the above tracing of JVP as normal, what is the most likely cause of lower tracing of JVP
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

The lower tracing of JVP represent large a with deep x descent. Y wave is absent in tamponade.

choices.text: It consists of a greater than 10 mmHg decrease in systolic arterial pressure with inspiration
It may be found in cases of severe obstructive lung disease
It is the reversal of normal phenomenon during inspiration
It is common in cases of cardiac tamponade

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true regarding pulsus paradoxus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Pulsus paradoxus is defined as systolic BP fall of >10mmHg on inspiration and is present in cases with severe respiratory distress, cardiac tamponade, & some cases of Chronic constrictive pericarditis. Normal inspiration also causes SBP fall of 2-9 mmHg; therefore, pulsus paradoxus is an exaggeration rather than the reversal of normal physiological phenomenon

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with fever and progressively increasing breathlessness since the last 2 weeks. His clinical examination reveals pulse 120/min regular, BP 90/60 mmHg, and muffled S1 & S2. The JVP is raised & has a prominent x descent, with an absent y descent. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
This is a case of cardiac tamponade. Hypotension, raised JVP, and muffled heart sounds are features of Beck’s triad for the diagnosis of cardiac tamponade

choices.text: Collapse of the right ventricle throughout systole on echocardiography
Collapse of the right ventricle during diastole on echocardiography
Rise of blood pressure during inspiration

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer develops exertional dyspnea and is found to have a large pericardial effusion, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. Which of the following signs is likely present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
This is a case of cardiac tamponade due to large pericardial effusion of metastasis from Carcinoma breast. In these cases, JVP is elevated & it shows the presence of prominent X descent but Y is obliterated. Kussmaul sign is never seen in these cases. The specific sign of cardiac tamponade on 2D Echo is RV diastolic collapse (Inward movement of RV free wall during diastole).

questions.text: Patient comes palpitation to ER. P-180/min, BP – 70mm of Hg systolic. ECG shows narrow qrs complex tachycardia with regular heart rate. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

PSVT is in shock, hence treatment Is Cardioversion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in CHADS2Vasc score to assess the risk of thromboembolism in atrial fibrillation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Coagulopathy

CHADS2Vasc score was developed to assess the risk of thromboembolism in non-rheumatic atrial fibrillation. Scores were alloted to various risk factors as follows:

Congestive heart failure: 1
History of hypertension: 1
Age > 75: 2 – Age between 65-75 :1 point
Diabetes: 1
Stroke / TIA: 2, Any other vascular event :1
Anticoagulation is indicated when CHADS2 score is >=2

questions.text: Cardioversion is indicated in following arrythmia when the patient develops hypotension EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Multifocal atrial tachycardia
MAT is commonly seen in ICU patients and is probably due to hyperactivity of the pacemaker cells due to elevated cytokine levels in the blood. Since the defect is not primarily in the heart, hypotension doesnot occur due to MAT itself and the treatment is directed towards management of the underlying cause. Cardioversion is not indicated

questions.text: In a patient with a wide-complex tachycardia, which ONE of the following ECG findings is not a marker of ventricular tachycardia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
The signs of Ventricular tachycardia on ECG are – Broad QRS > 140 msec, AV dissociation, Fusion & capture beats, QRS concordance, Atypical RBBB/LBBB, Extreme axis deviation

questions.text: What is the area marked ‘X’
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

ST interval

choices.text: Progressive prolongation of PR interval followed by a dropped QRS
Longest RR interval is less than twice the shortest RR interval

questions.text: Wenckebach’s AV block is characterised by all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Incremental increments in PR interval
•	The increments in PR interval in Wenckebach’s AV block are decremental. This is the reason for the progressive shortening of RR intervals

choices.text: Second degree AV block – Mobitz Type 1
Second degree AV block – Mobitz Type 2

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Second degree AV Block – Mobitz Type 2

questions.text: A 24 years old woman presents to the clinic with history of dyspnea on exertion class III. Her past history reveals rheumatic fever episode at 9 years of age. 2D Echo shows Mitral stenosis with MVA 1 cm2 and mobile non-calcified valve leaflets with no evidence of significant MR. Which of the following is the best therapeutic approach in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
In patients with isolated MS who have MVA (CRITICAL) less than 1 cm2 and symptomatic with NYHA class III/IV, the best therapeutic approach is Balloon Mitral Valvuloplasty. The contra-indications include associated significant MR, Calcified valve and LA thrombus

questions.text: In patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy maximum mutations are found in which gene
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Myosin heavy chain

Mutations in gene for b - Mysoin heavy chain are associated with 40% of the families with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
•	Troponin T mutations - 15% of the families
•	α - tropomyosin mutations ~5% of the families

questions.text: Giant "a" waves in the jugular vein can occur all of following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Aortic regurgitation.

  • "a" waves are the positive deflection in the jugular venous pulse following right atrial contraction.
  • This becomes giant in situations where the atrium is hypertrophied or contracts against resistance, such as constrictive pericarditis, pulmonary hypertension, and tricuspid stenosis or atresia

questions.text: Drug used in ventricular arrhythmia due to WPW syndrome is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Amiodarone

  • Amiodarone has been found effective in a wide range of ventricular and supraventricular arrhythmias.
  • Resistant VT and recurrent VF are the most important indications. It is also used to maintain sinus rhythm in AF when other drugs have failed.
  • Rapid termination of ventricular and supraventricular arrhythmias can be obtained by I.V. injection.

WPW tachyarrhythmia is terminated by suppression of both normal and aberrant pathways

questions.text: Patient comes to ER with chest pain of 3 hours duration and normal BP. ECG shows ST depression with ‘t’ inversion. Troponin levels are 140. Next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
NSTEMI – Hence Aspirin with Heparin

questions.text: Chest pain with ST elevation on ECG. Best test for diagnosis within 2-4 hours
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Heart specific Fatty acid binding protein rises in 2 hours.
Troponin and CpkMB rises 6-8 and 4-6 hours later respectively.
BNP is a marker of Heart failure and not used for diagnosis of ACS

questions.text: The presence of which of the following conditions portends the poorest longterm prognosis in patients with aortic stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
CHF
•	CHF has the poorest long-term prognosis at 2 years, while syncope and angina have a prognosis of 3 and 5 years respectively.
The valve area or calcification offer no information concerning prognosis

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic reperfusion arrhythmia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Accelerated idioventricular rhythm

•	Occurrence of an accelerated idioventricular rhythm during thrombolytic therapy of myocardial infarction is taken as an indicator of successful reperfusion. 
•	The other important evidences are prompt relief of pain and more than 50% resolution of ST segment elevation at 90 minutes

choices.text: Left bundle branch block pattern with ST segment elevation in right precordial leads.
Right bundle branch block pattern with ST segment depression in left precordial leads
Left bundle branch block pattern with ST segment elevation in left precordial leads.
Right bundle branch block pattern with ST segment elevation in leads V1 to V3

questions.text: Brugada syndrome is characterised by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Right bundle branch block pattern with ST segment elevation in leads V1 to V3.

  • Brugada syndrome was described by Brugada brothers, Pedro, Josep and Ramon, in their seminal paper in 1992. It is a inherited defect in the Slow Sodium channels of the pacemaker cells.
  • It has a propensity for life threatening ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death. Atrial arrhythmias have also been described recently.

Though drugs like quinidine, amiodarone and cilostozol have been noted to reduce the frequency of arrhythmia, the only life saving treatment option available is the implantation of an implantable cardioverter defibrillator

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy presents with severe dyspnea and bilateral inspiratory rales. What is the appropriate pharmacologic management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

β-adrenergic blocker

  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by asymmetric left ventricular hypertophy resulting in impaired relaxation and left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.
  • Maneuvers or pharmacologic agents that decrease preload (or increase chronotropy) will increase LVOT obstruction, thus worsening pulmonary congestion.
  • The cornerstone of therapy is decreased chronotropy to allow for increased diastolic filling time of the noncompliant left ventricle.
  • The end result is a decrease in both LVOT obstruction and pulmonary venous congestion.

Nitroglycerin, Nesiritide, and morphine will cause a reduction in preload and thus likely worsen the patient's clinical status

choices.text: Attacks maybe precipitated by tobacco and Cocaine
Maybe associated with Migraine and Raynaud’s phenomenon
Beta blockers are the treatment of choice

questions.text: Variant Angina is characterised by all EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Variant Angina is the other term for Prinz metal’s angina which is a result of coronary vasospasm. It most commonly affects middle aged females and is poorly related to exertion. It typically occurs in sleep between 12-5am.  30% cases maybe associated with other vasospastic disorders like migraine and Raynaud’s phenomenon. Attacks are usually precipitated by emotional stress/smoking/cocaine and amphetamine. ECG can show transient ST-T changes (elevation) suggesting Myocardial ischemia. Coronary angiography may reveal normal arteries. However, 50-60% may harbour significant coronary stenosis. Hence, provocative testing with ergonovine/intra-coronary acetylcholine is mandatory during angiography to demonstrate vasospasm. The treatment consists of Nitrates and CCB. Beta-blockers are best avoided because they may precipitate vasospasm by facilitating un-opposed alpha-action. Prognosis is excellent with <1% mortality

questions.text: A post-menopausal female presented with sudden onset angina. Coronary Angiography revealed normal vessels. Ventriculography performed in this patient during systole revealed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy – Stress induced cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart syndrome) is a unknown etiology transient myocardial ischemia syndrome common in postmenopausal females especially after intense emotional stimulus. Patients often present with chest pain, have ST-segment elevation on electrocardiography (ECG), and have elevated cardiac enzyme levels consistent with myocardial infarction (MI). However, when the patient undergoes cardiac angiography, left ventricular (LV) apical ballooning (as seen in the Question image – Takotsubo) is present, and there is no significant coronary artery stenosis.

The Japanese word takotsubo translates to "octopus pot," resembling the shape of the left ventricle during systole on imaging studies. 

The modified Mayo Clinic criteria for diagnosis of TCM  can be applied to a patient at the time of presentation. The diagnosis requires the presence of all four of the following:

  • Transient hypokinesis, dyskinesis, or akinesis of the LV midsegments, with or without apical involvement; the regional wall-motion abnormalities extend beyond a single epicardial vascular distribution, and a stressful trigger is often, but not always, present
  • Absence of obstructive coronary disease or angiographic evidence of acute plaque rupture
  • New ECG abnormalities (either ST-segment elevation and/or T-wave inversion) or modest elevation in the cardiac troponin level
  • Absence of pheochromocytoma or myocarditis

The prognosis in TCM is typically excellent, with nearly 95% of patients experiencing complete recovery within 4-8 weeks. Complications occur in 20% of TCM cases, particularly in the early stage

questions.text: A patient with Na+, 140; K+, 4.0; Cl-, 102; HCO3-, 12; Paco2 : 34 pH :7.26
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Mixed Metabolic acidosis and Respiratory acidosis.

Steps in ABG interpretation of ABB defects:

1. See the PH : Acidosis or Alkalosis

2. Check for primary disorder : Respiratory or metabolic

3. See for compensation.

a.IF primary was respiratory process , calculate metabolic compensation.

If primary was metabolic calculate respiratory compensation

b. If given value is within the expected value then it is a simple acid base disorder

c. If given value is not correlating with expected value then it will be a mixed disorder.

 

In given ABG report, Acidosis is correlating more to fall in HCO3 so its metabolic acidosis.

Expected PaCO2 = [1.5 × HCO3] +8 +-2 (Winter’s formula) that give the value of 24 to 28 mm hg.

In given case, PaCO2 is more than expected which will suggest an additional respiratory acidosis.

Hence, final diagnosis is Mixed Metabolic acidosis and Respiratory acidosis

questions.text: A 26-year-old male resident is noticed by his attending physician to have yellow eyes after his 24hour call period. When asked, the resident states he has no medical history, but on occasion, he has thought he might have mild jaundice when he is stressed or has more than four to five alcoholic drinks. He never sought medical treatment because he was uncertain, and his eyes would return fully to normal within 2 days. He denies nausea, abdominal pain, dark urine, light-colored stools, pruritus, or weight loss. On examination, he has a BMI of 20.1 kg/m2. Scleral icterus is present. There are no stigmata of chronic liver disease. Laboratory examinations are normal except for a total bilirubin of 3.0 mg/dL. Direct bilirubin is 0.2 mg/dL. AST, ALT, alkaline phosphatase and haptoglobin are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Gilbert’s syndrome
The given patient is presenting with an asymptomatic and mild elevation in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that has occurred during a time of increased stress, fatigue, and likely decreased caloric intake. This presentation is characteristic of Gilbert syndrome, an inherited disorder of bilirubin conjugation. In Gilbert syndrome, there is a mutation of the UGT1A1 gene that encodes bilirubin UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which leads to a reduction in activity on the enzyme to 10%–35% of normal. This enzyme is of critical importance in the conjugation of bilirubin. Most of the time, there is no apparent jaundice because the reduced ability to conjugate bilirubin is not reduced to a degree that leads to an elevation of bilirubin. However, during times of stress, fatigue, alcohol use, decreased caloric intake, or intercurrent illness, the enzyme can become overwhelmed, leading to a mild hyperbilirubinemia. Typical bilirubin levels are less than 4.0 mg/dL unless the individual is ill or fasting. Diagnosis usually occurs during young adulthood, and episodes are self-limiting and benign. If a liver biopsy were to be performed, hepatic histology would be normal. No treatment is necessary because there are no long-term consequences of Gilbert syndrome, and patient reassurance is recommended.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man developed painful swelling of his left knee and gives a history of diarrhoea 3 weeks back which resolved in 3 days. Testing for gonorrhoea is negative. Reactive arthritis associated with the recent enteric infection is suspected. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Post enteric reactive arthritis (also known as Reiter syndrome) typically develops 2–4 weeks after an acute diarrheal illness. It is an immune-mediated synovitis, so the synovial fluid shows an elevated leukocyte count despite the absence of infection. Gonococcal arthritis is important to exclude in a young person presenting with acute monoarticular arthritis. Shigella sp. is the most commonly associated enteric organism associated with this syndrome, other causes include Salmonella sp., Campylobacter jejuni, Yersinia enterocolitica, and even Clostridium difficile have been implicated.
Amoebic intestinal infections are not associated with reactive arthritis. People who develop this syndrome have a higher prevalence of HLA-B27 antigen, not HLADQ2, which is associated with celiac disease. 
This syndrome is more common in men and classically is associated with the triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman is seen in your office for evaluation of fatigue, malaise, and mild right upper quadrant discomfort, ongoing for the past 1 month. Her medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, and her only medication is levothyroxine. Her examination result is notable only for mildly tender hepatomegaly. On further questioning, she reports no risk factors for viral hepatitis. She does not consume alcohol or illicit drugs. Her mother has lupus, and a maternal aunt has rheumatoid arthritis.
Laboratory test results are notable for ALT 480 U/L, AST 211 U/L, total bilirubin 0.4 mg/dL, alkaline phosphatase 89 U/L, total protein 9.1 g/dL, albumin 4.1 g/dL, and TSH 2.1 µIU/mL. Her anti smooth muscle antibody titre is elevated. Which of the following statements about her likely diagnosis is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Treatment of choice is prednisone with azathioprine.
Patient’s elevated hepatic enzymes, female sex, elevated globulin levels (total protein, albumin), lack of risk factors for chronic viral hepatitis, personal history of hypothyroidism that could be autoimmune in nature, family history of autoimmune disorders, and high-titre anti–smooth
muscle antibody test are strong clues suggesting autoimmune hepatitis.
Autoimmune hepatitis is more common in women. Its Treatment consists of a glucocorticoid (such as prednisone) with azathioprine.
Undiagnosed and untreated autoimmune hepatitis may lead to the development of cirrhosis. Autoimmune hepatitis recurs in up to 50% of patients after liver transplant despite the immunosuppression regimen.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

It is usually caused by an adenoma of a single parathyroid gland.

  • "Primary HPT can be divided pathologically into adenoma, hyperplasia, and carcinoma. Adenomas clearly are the most prevalent entity representing 80-85% of cases.
  • Hyperplasia is the second most common diagnosis constituting 15% of cases. Carcinoma represents <1% of total cases.
  • Double adenoma has been found in approximately 5% of the time, and complicates the clinical distinction between adenoma and hyperplasia.
  • Histologically, normal parathyroid tissue shows a cell to fat ratio of 1:1. Hypercellular parathyroid tissue is typified by the loss of the normal amount of fat.
  • In primary hyperparathryroidism there is usually hypercalciuria. Secondary hyperparathyroidism may progress to tertiary but primary does not

questions.text: True regarding pseudohypoparathyroidism include all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Pseudohypoparathyroidism is genetic disorder characterized by symptoms and signs of hypoparathyroidism, typically in association with distinctive skeletal and developmental defects. The hypoparathyroidism is due to a deficient end-organ response to PTH. Hyperplasia of the parathyroid, a response to hormone resistance, causes elevation of PTH levels. 
Most patients show characteristic features of Albright dystrophy, consisting of short stature, round face, skeletal anomalies (brachydactyly), and heterotopic calcification. Patients have low calcium and high phosphate levels, as with true hypoparathyroidism. PTH levels, however, are elevated, reflecting resistance to hormone action

Features of Meningoccal Meningitis

  • Nausea

questions.text: A 30- year old man is noted to be hypertensive. A complete blood count reveals mild leukocytosis, hematocrit of 55% ,and thrombocytosis. Uric acid is elevated and ultrasound confirms splenomegaly. Comment on the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Polycythemia vera      

  • Patients with spurious polycythemia frequently are dehydrated and volume contracted; with future –hyderation, their hematocrit may indeed normalize.
  • There is usually no evidence of a true myeloproliferative disorder, including splenomegaly or extensive thrombocytosis.
  • Patients with secondary polycythemia frequently have underlining chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and an elevation in red blood cell mass as a compensatory mechanism.
  • Patients with true polycythemia vera usually have significant splenomegaly, elevated leukocyte alkaline phosphatase, and frequently also exhibit leukocytosis and thrombocytosis

choices.text: Antibiotics should be given if a source of infection can be identified

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is found to have acute leukemia. Three weeks after initiation of chemotherapy he has a body temperature spike to 38.9 C (102 F), with a white blood cell count of 500/mm. Which of the following is true regarding this clinical situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Bacteremia, if present, would most likely be caused by pseudomonas and other gram-negative bacilli

  • The leading cause of death in cancer patients is infection. Fever developing during the course of treatment for cancer demands careful investigation for infection by all classes of pathogens: bacteria, viruses, yeasts, and protozoans.
  • Pneumonia is common but difficult to diagnose. There is scant sputum production, and often the chest roentgenographic findings are misleadingly normal. Gram-negative bacilli are responsible for most pneumonias and bacteremias.
  • The skin, mucous membranes, and catheter sites are common portals of entry. In the absence of an obvious source of infection, it is essential to begin empirical antibiotic therapy aimed at the most common organisms.
  • An antipseudomonal penicillin plus an aminoglycoside is a commonly used regimen.
  • Both chemotherapy and the tumor lysis syndrome can cause fever, but infection is much more likely to be the cause

  • C5a is an anaphylatoxin

questions.text: Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is characterized by all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Hypercalcemia
Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is an oncologic emergency that is caused by massive tumor cell lysis with the release of large amounts of potassium, phosphate, and nucleic acids into the systemic circulation. The metabolic consequences include hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, secondary hypocalcemia, hyperuricemia, and acute kidney injury. High levels of both uric acid and phosphate increase the severity of acute kidney injury because uric acid precipitates readily in the presence of calcium phosphate crystals, and calcium phosphate precipitates readily in the presence of uric acid crystals.

questions.text: The most common cause of Humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM) is

There are several distinct humoral causes of HHM, but it is caused most commonly by overproduction of PTHrP

questions.text:
A 60year old woman is admitted with sudden onset of chest pain and is diagnosed with an acute myocardial infarction. Her acute illness is complicated by low blood pressure and poor tissue perfusion for several days. Her serum Urea and Creatinine are noted to be increasing. On day 1 – Urea – 8, Creatinine – 1.16

Day 2 – Urea – 22 Creatinine – 1.40

Day 3- Urea – 30  creatinine -2.0

Granular and Hyaline cast are present in the urine. The renal lesion is most likely to be present in this situation is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Acute Tubular Necrosis

questions.text: A 40 year old male presented with 10 days history of Fever , severe joint pains and headache. He was treated with antibiotics by a doctor previously but he didn’t respond. On examination he was found to have high BP , features of inflammatory arthritis in large joints , gangrene in 2 fingers of upper limb and a skin lesion as given in the picture below. Investigations revealed high creatinine without proteinuria or hematuria. ANA and ANCA were negative. HbsAg turned out +ve but the patient ultimately succumbed to abdominal perforation. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Systemic symptoms in a middle aged man
Non infective fever
Hypertension with renal failure without proteinuria points towards renovascular pathology
Gangrene and Livedo reticularis on skin
Hep B associated
ANA /  ANCA –ve

questions.text: All of the following are known to cause drug induced Lupus except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Tacrolimus

DRUG INDUCED LUPUS : (DIL)

  1. Drugs causing lupus are: Procainamide, hydralazine, ACEI, Thiazides, Alpha-methyldopa, isoniazid, sulphonamides, chlorpromazine, D-Penicillamine, quinidine, interferon alpha and possibly hydantoin, ethosuximide, proton pump inhibitor, Anti-TNF-alpha agents and oral contraceptives.
  2. Procainamide is the most frequent offender followed by hydralazine.
  3. Clinical manifestation include fever, malaise, arthritis, serositis and rash.
  4. Renal and CNS involvement are rare. All patients have ANA and most have antibodies to histones.
  5. Antibodies to dsDNA and hypocomplementemia are rare (a helpful point in distinguishing drug-induced from idiopathic lupus).

questions.text: The following statements are true regarding Sjogren’s syndrome EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Sjogren’s syndrome is characterised by dryness (sicca) of eyes and mouth due to chronic lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. It is either Idiopathic(primary) where the Sjogren’s is the disease. This form is associated with increased risk of systemic involvement and lymphoma. Circulating high titres of SSA/SSB antibodies pre-dispose to lymphoma

questions.text: Following are features of Spondyloarthropathies EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

SpA have Excellent response to NSAIDS which are the first line of treatment.

SpA are a group of diorders sharing following features:

a. Seronegative : RAF Negative

b. Strong family history of arthropathy : HLA-B27+

c. Axial involvement : not uncommon

d. Primary site of joint involvement is Enthesitis

e. Extra-articular symptoms precede the arthritis

f. Excellent response to steroids

questions.text: Following statements about SLE are true EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Belimumab is a monoclonal antibody against B-lymphocyte stimulator (Blys), found to reduce disease activity and possibly decrease the number of severe flares and steroid use in patients with SLE when used in combination with standard therapy.
Vitamin D3 deficiency is more common in SLE patients and supplementation is helpful.
Hydroxychloroquine is the cornerstone of therapy and also safe in pregnancy
